												Eufloria HD is an upgraded version of the original Eufloria, which I also played. Both games are an extremely relaxing and atmospheric strategy based on some gameplay mechanics from simpler flash strategy titles: capture planets (here called asteroids), upgrade them (here with beautiful trees that grow over time) and they will generate units (here called seedlings) over time, then use said units to flood other asteroids. Take over the map and you win. Rinse and repeat.Despite the fact that the games tend to reach a certain tipping point where it becomes easy to overwhelm your enemies, Eufloria is a very polished take on this idea, and a lot of fun to boot! The soundtrack is very mellow, and the visuals are clean and beautiful. This version upgrades the visuals and adds some new mechanics, such as the ability to upgrade asteroids which have poor stats by sacrificing seedlings, and rallying points which means less needless clicking and dragging.There is a solid story mode that can take about 10 hours to complete (or more depending on what speed you play at), as well as arcade levels and a New Game + mode. Overall, a decent amount of content for the price.Honestly, I cannot recommend this game enough! It has a great, calming atmopshere, some straightforward but satisfying RTS gameplay and a solid campaign and arcade mode. Definitely worth the price!

Eufloria  Field Rating Review   Graphics 9 Eufloria gets a solid nod for the artistic approach it took to graphics. This game weaves together a beautiful living picture as you play, with pleasant and relaxing aesthetics, from sound to visuals.    Gameplay 7 A wonderfully relaxing game, Eufloria is great to sit down and play when you're looking to just chill out. Mesmerizing in style, with a downtone soundtrack, Eufloria offers up a unique take on strategy games. Taking a much more tug of war approach, you grow your seeds (altering their stats via another artful gameplay mechanic) and work to overwhelm the opposing forces. Eventually it becomes a domino effect as you send wave after gigantic wave of units from planet to planet, toppling over the enemy's forces. However, it can be a bit tedious at times waiting for your army to grow enough to make your next move, particularly at the start of each game. This problem is few and far between though, as several times you are under immediate pressure to act.   Story 3 You probably won't find yourself caring much about the story of this game, as it is strange and vague most the time.   Multiplayer N/A None to be found here.   Replayability 5 Eufloria is one of those games you come to when you need it. For me, that particular time is when I need to wind down and relax. Each time coming back is enjoyable though.   Overall 6/10 Don't get confused by the 6 over there, that's still a good number. I definitely recommend Eufloria to anyone that enjoys sitting down and playing a chill game. If you're looking for fast paced action this game is not for you. Eufloria is a moment of calm in a storm of run-and-gun, spray-and-pray, leap-then-look games. 												This game isn't bad, exactly, I mean playing it isn't a negative experience.  It's just unengaging.  It's a game made for tablets (pretty obvious from the UI), but it knows what it is and doesn't try to be anything else, so I can't hold that against it.  Unfortunately what the game does try to be is...not very ambitious.There is absolutely no strategy involved - the solution to every level is "amass several hundred units and steamroll through the map."  There is only one unit, and while some have more speed or more strength, none of that matters because overwhelming numbers trumps all in this game. There are 25 levels, and every single one of them plays the same way.The game easy, but intentionally so - it's supposed to be a relaxing game, which it is for the most part, the music and visuals are really well done!  Unfortunately, towards the last couple of levels, the game resorts to cheap methods of increasing difficulty, like having your enemies start the level controlling more units and more territory on the map.  You may end up restarting a level several times, hoping the enemy will decide not to attack you in the first 5 minutes this time and totally wipe you out.And there is so.  Much.  WAITING.  Waiting for your trees to grow.  Waiting for more seedlings to spawn.  Not helped by the fact that everything happens at an incredibly sluggish pace, and even on the fastest time setting, you can still Alt-Tab to your browser once in a while without fear.TL;DR: This is a game that is meant to be played while you do something else.  It's a game meant to waste time.  You'll never wake up one day and get the urge to play some more Eufloria, so I can't really recommend it.  But if you're stuck at your parents' house for Christmas and your $3000 PC is back home and all you have is your dinky laptop, then yeah, Eufloria will distract you for a bit.

												An enjoyable, relaxing RTS game with great atmosphere.  Don't be fooled by my playtime, I played the original Eufloria years ago, and it's still in my Steam top-20 with nearly 50 hours played.  Impressive for a small indie game, especially if you consider I don't generally like RTS games.  And now these wonderful developers decided to gift the new improved HD version to everyone who bought the original game.The game isn't complicated at all, the tutorial levels do a great job to teach you all you need to know.  You start with seedlings around an asteroid under your control.  You can move them to other asteroids within your influence sphere, possibly attacking enemy seedlings in the process, or plant them to grow a tree.  Trees produce seedlings, with increasing output overtime when they become fully grown.  Seedlings come with 3 characteristics, based on the quality of the asteroid they were grown on : energy, strength and speed.  Strength and speed are obvious, higher energy means you will need less seedlings to conquer an enemy asteroid.  Some more complexity later on, but those are the basics in a nutshell.What makes this game great is the atmosphere, sound & graphics.   It really looks gorgeous, with a high attention to detail (e.g. seedlings stats also change the way they look).  You notice how the developers really made this with a passion.  The levels are partially procedurally generated, the level will never be identical, but some parameters stay the same.  The music is nice and relaxing.  You also have a lot of control over the speed of the game, allowing for both rushed gameplay or a relaxing experience.If I have to mention something negative, the only thing I can think of is the lack of complexity.  Levels start to feel too similar after awhile, because you are growing seedlings and invading asteroids over and over again.  There is some variation in each level's initial strategy, but usually it's pretty obvious if you have to grow, attack or flee to beat the level.

WRITTEN FOR EUFLORIA CLASSICIt seems I can't post a review for that one anymore, so I'll just add it here. Thanks, Gabe.Man, was I tricked by Eufloria or what? I played it briefly, not even maybe half an hour or so in total, couple of years ago and was left with the impression it was an easy game you play more to relax than anything else accompanied by a really mellow tunes to kick back to. Needless to say, my initial formulation was wrong so let's get into just how badly I misjudged the game.At its core Eufloria is what it says on the tin – strategy game where you control Euflorians, race that exists to plant their Dyson trees on various asteroids you come across over 25 story levels game has to offer, and explore the universe in the process. Plot does reveal itself more with time and you realize there are far graver things at stake here, but game never indulges in full-blown narrative or anything like that. Simple text popups at the beginning of each mission and sometimes during will suffice. In my opinion anything more overbearing would suffocate the great mood game has going on no matter what's happening on the screen.When it comes to gameplay things aren't that simple as each asteroid, depending on size, has a “jump range” that effectively limits how far you can travel initially which translates into gradual expansion from your starting position. As far as your Dyson trees go there are two types; seedling-producing and defensive trees which generate mines for self-defense. Yes, you read that correctly and there is, in fact, combat in the game as not all asteroids you come across are actually empty and there are other Euflorians, I suppose, doing their own thing just like you. Once your seedlings approach an already occupied asteroid you will have to fight it out first before you can begin assailing asteroid's core energy and claim it by expending units to build your first tree. If any other trees survive the siege you will also assume control of those so it might be worthwhile to actually take over developed locations and not just build from the ground up. Big determining factor in this is that asteroids have their defining attributes: Speed, Strength and Energy, all of which carry over to seedlings you spawn from that asteroid's Dyson trees. I feel like I'm over-complicating this and game neatly color codes everything for you so there's no problem there, with things like no real resources except your seedling making it even simpler to put together.Where problems start to rear their head is when you realize this isn't just a “select your troops and ATTACK” all the time or at least until you have an overwhelming force to your name. In particular, later on when scenarios get more complex and you need to devise specific situations in order to advance. From simultaneously trading bases with your enemy so he can bait other enemies and distract them for you, to essentially protecting the enigmatic Grey in order to study them game does vary it up a bit even though at its core it's all about conquering mass and building on top of it. I really enjoyed when things like flowers and laser mines got introduced and opened up your pretty basic strategies. There is a weird sensation to be found in throwing hundreds after hundreds of seedling-warriors at the enemy and taking away his asteroids one by one... only to end up dismayed when you lose it all because you recklessly rushed forward and ran into a fully fortified asteroid. Somewhat procedurally generated levels don't help in blindly repeating your mistakes so it's back to school time and actually paying attention to what you're doing.I must say soundtrack by Milieu really adds to the overall package, though. It helps you stay calm and plan your actions coolly even when you're not simply drifting away listening during moments of idleness and nail-biting empire building. When time comes for forces to clash it may seem out of place for such atmospheric electronica to take front stage, but it strangely fits. Nothing but praise and I hope to hear it elsewhere someday.So let's cut to the chase – should you play Eufloria? If you know what you're getting into and don't get bamboozled like me. Through no fault of the game, mind you. I merely formulated my opinion way too early and paid the price. Later levels WILL tax you and it stops being a breeze at half-way point, but I've also heard people say game is too easy and even more challenging Dark Matter mode exists for those people so maybe I'm just not suited for this one.It was certainly an experience.

												Eufloria HD is a zen-out RTS. You play as Freeman Dyson.I would say that the game is an embodiment of good simpleness, in many ways. Regarding the gameplay, it isn't unchallenging, but it is straightforward RTS in design; you've got your scouting, expanding, conflict, and some asset improvement—it doesn't try to overcomplicate itself. Its visuals are also quite simple, using a minimalistic style, which evokes images of insects and plants. It has chill electronic ambient music playing throughout play, never trying to do anything too complicated with its sound, and meshing quite well with the game's all around simplicity. It doesn't try to reinvent the Stanford torus, it's just a good simple game.Improvements made in Eufloria HD over Eufloria look like they have either a console or a mobile version responsible for their existence. This isn't a bad thing. While the UI isn't as purely minimalistic as was in the original, it's far more functional, allowing the player much more manual control over their harvests of seedlings; an example would be splitting a large swarm of seedlings, one half to intercept attackers of one of your undefended asteroids, while sending the other half to punish the attackers for leaving their own asteroid open. In the original, your options were to send all, or if you wanted to split forces, you were required exactly as many right-clicks as units you intended to send, or right-hold, and get a number kind of close to what you wanted; neither of which were quick. There are also now options to filter what you want to send where by traits, without delving into 100% micromanagement. In addition to the improved control over large swarms, due to the addition of beacons to direct where newly spawned seedlings go, building those large swarms is now much easier. Altogether, I feel that these are substantial improvements to the flow of gameplay, removing a large amount of frustration and tedium that wore the zen thin.While I loved the originals, both Dyson and Eufloria, for what they were, Eufloria HD has finally resolved its prior versions' major gameplay flaws, which worked counter to the chill environment its developers envisioned. With that in mind, I can now give the game my wholehearted recommendation for anyone looking for a nice little RTS to relax with. Even if you find its full price a bit of an ask, there are much worse things you could put in your cart during a sale.I should note, that due to the simple monochrome backgrounds with bright neon seedlings, the game lends itself quite well to the Tetris effect.

												I've spent well over 100 hours playing this on console back in the day. I'm a little rusty at it now, but I have to say that this is one of, if not THE best, strategy game I've ever played. It's not particularly complex; you are in control of seedlings looking to colonise asteroids in some distant future. You use seedlings to fight enemy seedlings, scout out out unknown asteroids and grow trees that allow you to populate your seedling army, or protect your own asteroid. Each asteroid has 3 traits that determine what attributes your seedlings will have when they grow; energy, strength, and speed.That's essentially it, but with these basics rules the game becomes heart pounding. The first few sections are basic tutorials, but after a couple of hours you are waging wars against hundreds and hundreds of enemies, wars of attrition and patience. Holding key asteroids on the front lines, and managing which asteroids will become seedling producers and for what traits, becomes crucial in large battles. I've had games last for hours because of the attrition warfare, and because of how relaxed the game is. Timing is also key; do you rush an enemy asteroid in an instant to secure a quick victory, all the while leaving another asteroid unguarded? Or do you slowly build your force, moving from asteroid to asteroid, claiming each for your own in a slow but secure campaign?The art style is a huge draw for this game. It's something I can't quite describe. With simplistic but vibrant colours, and a beautiful soundtrack by Milieu, the game lies somewhere between a surreal nature documentary and some kind of 1970's late-night cartoon fever-dream. I spent many gloomy days being absorbed into a kind of trance because of the visuals and sounds. Overall I'd very much recommend this title if you are even a passing fan of RTS or somewhat relaxing games. One thing I will say is that I personally prefer using a controller for this, but it's equally as playable with a mouse

												A 3X strategy game sporting a minimalistic art direction is given fresh life in Eufloria HD. Eschewing complex space combat, which is the dominating genre for the 4X game, in Eufloria you take on the guise of a organic army that has set out to plant itself around the game space. Eufloria sports a couple of "super units" each with their own special abilities, two types of "base structures" and a simple upgrade system which adds depth to an deceptively complex strategy game. Not many hours of first-play-through time, but at its standard low price its quite enjoyable. Once you have defeated the campaign it garners replayability through "arena" modes and a second play through of the campaign at higher difficulty, entitled "Dark Mode." I recommend this.

												Long story short: I love itI've clocked in... too many hours playing this game in it's original form. I enjoy this sort of game though I'm sure it's not for everyone - try the demo first if you're concerned. The updated HD version is a little bit different in the mechanics but I've already gotten used to it and I think it's for the best. My work requires that I be rather creative and that can be a big mental drain sometimes. This game has been a great way for me to wind down after a long day. There's still plenty of thinking involved but the ambient sounds/music makes a relaxing atmostphere even when my minions are getting slaughtered. I also appreciate the fact that the game doesn't really force me to be something I'm not - there are some levels where speed or sneakiness wins the day but typically, you play the strategy you like best and as long as you play well, you'll win. The storyline is fairly simple, just enough to carry you from mission to mission, teaching you different strategies. I kind of wish more games taught this way in their campaign modes. Maybe to some it seems like hand-holding, though. Regardless, I appreciate not having to think so hard in a game while still feeling engaged.The downsides: not much. It is what it is - an 'ambient strategy game'. Sometimes the really big missions get a bit boring when you have to wait for enough seedlings to accumulate in order to make a key move. The new speed change option in the HD version pretty much fixes that issue for me, however. But still no co-op. I think they're could be great potential there... maybe in Eufloria 2 or something?

												What makes this game a favorite of mine is its chill and comfortable atmosphere. You can just get lost in managing your seedlings, also thanks to the nice ambient music.Game-wise, the idea is interesting, The controls are intuitive at first, but can get messy as the the amount of planets, seedling-types and other items grows. Some advanced key-shortcuts would maybe have been a good idea, but then again I guess the game is also meant to be played with simple controls (I played more of it on my android phone than on the pc)The balancing is so-so. I feel that some levels can only get won by taking huge risks (rushing), and imo there are levels where you can get into a deadlock, as neither you nor the enemy can win anymore, it just becomes a continous cycle of you going all out taking the planet(s), the enemy recovering, him going all out, repeat ..
